The elder Cunda knelt with his palms joined and said to the Buddha:
People in the world accumulate wealth, thinking and worrying, not daring to enjoy themselves, not knowing to give in charity, or to uphold the precepts. There is no respect or humility.

Those who obtain what they wish for, may sometimes die. Parents, brothers, wives, and relatives cry and grieve. For their coffins and shrouds, they send wealth, treasures, clothes, and food. Can this benefit the dead?
The Buddha told Cunda and the disciples assembled:
Listen to what I say and think about it well!
Cunda's relatives and the disciples assembled all joined their palms, focused their minds, received the teachings, and listened.
The Buddha said:
People have four wishes that cannot always be preserved.
What are the four?
The first wish is for this human body.
Bathing, adorning, food, and the five pleasures are always given to it first, but when a sudden illness strikes, it cannot be stopped.
When life ends, the strong body remains on the ground, not following the person's spirit and soul, and only heavy love for it, what benefit is there again?
The second wish is for having wealth, official rank, and salary.
Those who obtain it are happy, those who do not obtain it are sorrowful.
When illness strikes and life ends, all the wealth, official rank, and salary remain in the world, not following the person's spirit and soul, and only cause sorrow.
The third wish is for having parents, siblings, spouse and children, relatives inside and outside, friends, acquaintances, loved ones, and glory and joy.

They will cry in vain and send me outside the city to a deep grave, abandoning me and returning home quickly.

Although they may think of me and grieve and worry, it will not last more than ten days. The families and relatives, men and women gathered together, will face each other, singing and dancing, happily eating and drinking, talking and laughing, forgetting about the dead person.
Even if there are parents, brothers, wives and children, inner and outer relatives, friends and acquaintances, they cannot accompany me in the afterlife. What benefit is there in their vain grief?
The fourth vow is for this person's mind.

Few people in the world can guard their minds. They let their minds run wild, indulge in the five desires, greedily pursue profit, are jealous, angry, and quarrel, and do not believe in morality and virtue.

When the body dies and life ends, the soul departs, and the three [parts] chase each other, unable to separate. It is like a bird flying, with the mind following its two wings, and the mind being the soul and spirit, with the two wings being the hun and po souls.

People cannot guard their minds, and all do evil thoughts, killing, stealing, coveting, and lusting. Due to the sins committed in life, after death they enter the Taishan Hell, becoming hungry ghosts.
After the punishment is over, they are born as animals, to be slaughtered by humans.
Because people let their minds run wild and indulge themselves, they enter the three evil paths.
The Buddha told Cunda and his disciples:
You should be upright in your minds and guard your thoughts!
Contemplate carefully and think:
Know that the body is not your self, and the possessions you have are not yours to keep.

One should carefully consider all the parents, brothers, wives, children, five kinds of relatives, friends, acquaintances, official positions, and salaries that one has, thinking of obtaining them, never being content, thinking that they are beneficial to one's body, but when old age, sickness, and death come, they cannot benefit one's body, nor can they ward them off for one.
People cannot save themselves and pursue the Way, just like a parrot that loves its feathers and tail, and is caught by a hunter.
The wise should know that these four desires do not follow the human soul and spirit, and are in vain for one's suffering.
Therefore, one should uproot the roots of affection and love, cut off the paths of the three evil destinies, and attain the paths of the three good destinies:
First, one will not grow old again;
Second, one will not fall sick again;
Third, one will not die again.
Firmly guarding one's mind, one may then attain liberation!
When the disciples heard the sutra, they rejoiced and bowed to the Buddha.

The Buddha Speaks the SÅ«tra of Four Vows The Buddha thinks of the myriad things outside the eight directions of heaven and earth, all endowed with a nature that harbors worries and suffering, always injuring the people and wriggling creatures, unable to be free.
Competing with heaven for life, all will return to death.
The bones decay and rot, and enter the earth below;
The spirit soars and wanders, transmigrating through the five paths, doing good to ascend to heaven, doing evil to enter the abyss.
When ordinary people are born, the good and evil they do, the spirit and soul, follow their blessings and misfortunes.
When born as a human, being filial to parents and loyally serving the ruler, one ascends to heaven after death.
Like worldly people, accumulating virtue and doing good, seeking official positions through service, reaching the rank of duke or becoming wealthy and noble.
Wealth and happiness, poverty and hardship, all result from past lives.
Engaging in killing and cruelty, one is born as an evil person and after death receives heavy retribution.
Acting as the lord of one's own mind invites a hundred misfortunes, the joy of a wanton mind will certainly have later troubles.
The emperor and the people are all confused about the Way.
Relying on parents.
Doing good brings blessings and longevity, doing evil brings poverty and suffering.
Stealing from others, owing debts without repayment, borrowing without returning, after death one will become a slave, ox or horse, or a large pig, slaughtered and skinned, sold to repay debts.

As a human, being stingy and greedy, unwilling to give, after death one becomes a hungry ghost, not obtaining clothing or food, like a beggar, cutting flesh with a knife, begging for food with one's head bowed.
All of these are from previously being greedy, rebellious, and not believing in doing good.

Harming, killing, stealing, taking others' wives and daughters, slanderous and divisive speech, drinking and fighting, after death one enters hell, whipped, burned, and boiled, with extreme pain and suffering.

People have six worries, three sufferings, and four pains. The Buddha subdues and transforms them, but birth and death continue endlessly. He abandoned his country and renounced the throne to seek the natural Way. Accumulating virtue for many years, he finally attained true enlightenment.
His spiritual clarity penetrated and illuminated, seeing everything outside of the heavens and earth. He knew the words and intentions of humans, birds, beasts, insects, and reptiles.
The Buddha thought that when people die, it is like a great wind suddenly arriving without warning.
When death arrives without time, one should struggle with one's mind and do good without doubt.
The Buddha encourages the wise with the scriptures and the Way. What unseen by the eyes and unheard by the ears, what rare and precious things, how can they benefit oneself?
Those who practice the Way should believe in the scriptures and precepts, keep goodness and die, not commit evil and be born. The Way cannot be lost, and virtue cannot be separated from.
Far from the Way and losing virtue is like a child born without a mother or a fish escaping from a deep pool.
When a person dies and is reborn, it is like a silkworm spinning a cocoon, breaking through the silk to fly out. The spirit remains the same, but the form changes and the shell is replaced.
The Way is accomplished in the subtle, and the five precepts take root.
The disciples joyfully received the teaching upon hearing the sutra, and this is the recognition of pain and itch as one truly knows it.
What is the recognition of thought?
It is the six thoughts of the body.
Eye-contemplation thought, ear, nose, mouth, body, and mind-contemplation thought.
Such are the six thoughts.
What is the recognition of the practice of thought?
Contemplation practice is the practice of thought, such is the recognition of the practice of thought.
What is the recognition of the cessation of thought?
The cessation of contemplation is the recognition of the cessation of thought, such is the recognition of the cessation of thought.
What is the recognition of the practice of receiving the cessation of thought?
This is the recognition of the eight practices.
The recognition of the eight is the recognition of the eight, such as the recognition of the cessation of thought and the practice of receiving it.
What is the consciousness of the taste of thoughts?
It is the arising of pleasure and joy that is conditioned by thoughts. This is the consciousness of the taste of thoughts.
What is the consciousness of the marrow of thoughts?
It is the impermanence, suffering, and change of thoughts. This is the consciousness of the marrow of thoughts.
What is the consciousness of the abandonment of thoughts?
It is the understanding, cutting off, and transcendence of desire and greed in thoughts. This is the consciousness of the abandonment of thoughts.
What is the consciousness of birth and death?

It is the consciousness of the birth and death of the six sense bases. The consciousness of the birth and death of the eye sense base, the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind sense bases. This is the consciousness of birth and death.
What is the consciousness of the arising of birth and death, the arising of the arising of birth and death?
What is the consciousness of the cessation of birth and death?
The cessation is the consciousness of the cessation of birth and death.
What is the consciousness of the practice leading to the cessation of desire for birth and death?
Are these the eight kinds of consciousness? The view of the truth up to the concentration of the truth are the eight. Thus, the desire to end birth and death is the consciousness of the practice.
What is the consciousness of the taste of birth and death?
The pleasure and joy that arise from the causes and conditions of birth and death - this is the consciousness of the taste of birth and death.
What is the consciousness of the marrow of birth and death?
The impermanence, suffering, and change of the Dharma of birth and death - this is the consciousness of the marrow of birth and death.
What is the consciousness of the essence of birth and death?
The desire and attachment to birth and death, the ability to cut off desire and transcend - this is the consciousness of the essence of birth and death.
What is the consciousness of the six sense bases of the body?
The consciousness of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind - this is the consciousness of the consciousness.
What is the practice of consciousness?
The practice of the name of life is the practice of consciousness. This is how consciousness is practiced.
What is the end of consciousness?
The end of the name of life is the end of consciousness. This is the end of consciousness.
What is the knowledge of the end of consciousness?
The eightfold path, from right view to right concentration, is the eightfold path. Thus, the knowledge of the end of desire and the practice of the path is the knowledge of the truth.
What is the knowledge of the taste of what is to be known?
Because of conditions, joy and pleasure arise in the mind. Thus, the arising of taste is the knowledge of the taste of what is to be known.
What is the knowledge of the marrow of what is to be known?
To end suffering and to transcend, this is the knowledge of the marrow of what is to be known.
What is the knowledge of the essence of what is to be known?
Desire and greed can sustain, desire and greed can cut off and transcend. Thus, this is the knowledge of the essence.

The seven bases are to be known through awakening.
What are the seven?
Form, its arising, its ending, the path, its taste, its danger, and its escape.
Each of the five aggregates has seven things.
What are the three kinds of knowledge?
There are also seven things, obtaining the five aggregates to form the six sense bases.
Contemplating the body as one form, contemplating the five aggregates as two, and contemplating the six sense bases as three, thus it is said to be three contemplations.

The Buddha spoke like this.
